g.text: T R E N D S
or additional procedures for cleaning and disin-
processing, which are available in CDCâ€™s 2003
infection control guidelines for dental health care
are not indicated after treating patients
beyond the scope of this article to review specific
diseases; however, I mention some briefly as
isms pass from an infected person to a healthy
person via direct physical contact with blood or
body fluids. Examples of direct contact in health
care settings are touching, contact with oral
secretions or contact with body lesions. Infectious
microorganisms also can be transferred indirectly
via a contaminated intermediate object or person.
Contaminated hands frequently are cited as a sig-
nificant source of indirect contact transmission.
Other modes of indirect contact transmission
include percutaneous injuries sustained via a con-
taminated needle or other sharp object and
instruments, surfaces and equipment that are not
properly cleaned and disinfected or sterilized
Contact Precautions are intended to prevent
transmission of infectious agents that are spread
by direct or indirect contact with the patient or
the patientâ€™s environment. Examples of conditions
Select conditions and diseases requiring Transmission-Based
Until lesions are dry and crusted
Five days, except DI in people who
Seven days from symptom onset or
Four days after onset of rash,
except DI in people who are
U seven days after onset of rash
DI plus 10 days after resolution of
DI until all scabs have crusted and
therapy is improving clinically and has
Until lesions are dry and crusted
* Transmission-Based Precautions always are used in addition to Standard Precautions.
â€¡ X: Use or apply the precaution.
Â¶ DI: Duration of illness (with wound lesions, DI means until wounds stop draining).
# U: Until time specified in hours or days after initiation of effective therapy.
